qas.question: What drugs reduce the risk of death and other events in people with ACE?

context: A <a4_0><a7_0><b12_0>2009<b12_0/><a7_0/><a4_0/> <a2_0><b10_0>Cochrane<b10_0/><a2_0/> review concluded that <a1_0><a6_0><b9_0>thiazide antihypertensive drugs<b9_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/> reduce the risk of death (RR 0.89), stroke (RR 0.63), coronary heart disease (RR 0.84), and cardiovascular events (RR 0.70) in people with high blood pressure. In the ensuring years other classes of antihypertensive drug were developed and found wide acceptance in <a3_0><b11_0>combination therapy<b11_0/><a3_0/>, including loop diuretics (Lasix/furosemide, Hoechst Pharmaceuticals, 1963), beta blockers (ICI Pharmaceuticals, 1964) ACE inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers. <a5_0>ACE inhibitors<a5_0/> <a0_0><b8_0>reduce the risk of new onset kidney disease [RR 0.71] and death [RR 0.84] in diabetic patients<b8_0/><a0_0/>, irrespective of whether they have hypertension.
